Balanced Mulching: Apply a moderate amount of mulch to conserve moisture without causing excessive dampness.

Soil Aeration: Avoid deep tilling to preserve soil moisture.
REMEDIAL MEASURE - FLOOD:
Fast Drainage System: Improve drainage through open channels to remove excess water quickly.

Temporary Furrows: Create furrows between rows to divert excess water away from the root zone.

Use of Absorbents: Apply biochar, rice husk, or well-draining sand to absorb excess soil moisture.

Disease Prevention: Monitor for fungal diseases such as boll rot, root rot, and leaf blight, and apply appropriate organic or chemical fungicides.

Soil Aeration: Lightly till the topsoil after water recedes to restore oxygen supply.

Avoid Soil Compaction: Prevent heavy machine or foot traffic in waterlogged fields.

Replanting Strategy: If young plants are severely damaged, consider replanting with short-duration cotton varieties.

Use of Absorbents: Apply biochar, rice husk, or well-draining sand to absorb excess soil moisture.

Disease Prevention: Monitor for fungal diseases such as boll rot, root rot, and leaf blight, and apply appropriate organic or chemical fungicides.

Soil Aeration: Lightly till the topsoil after water recedes to restore oxygen supply.

Avoid Soil Compaction: Prevent heavy machine or foot traffic in waterlogged fields.

Replanting Strategy: If young plants are severely damaged, consider replanting with short-duration cotton varieties.

Raised Beds or Ridges: Improves drainage and prevents water stagnation around roots.

Soil Aeration: Avoid deep tilling to preserve soil moisture.

Soil Aeration: Lightly till the soil after water recedes to improve oxygen levels.

Avoid Soil Compaction: Prevent foot or machinery traffic in waterlogged fields.

Replanting Strategy: If plants are severely damaged, replant with short-duration millet varieties.

Water Conservation Strategies: Store rainwater in farm ponds for later use.

Controlled Irrigation: Reduce watering frequency, as wetland soils retain moisture longer.

Raised Beds or Ridges: Prevents water stagnation, ensuring proper aeration for the roots.

Balanced Mulching: Apply moderate mulch to retain moisture without causing excess dampness.
REMEDIAL MEASURE - FLOOD:
Quick Drainage System: Create open channels to remove standing water efficiently.

Use Absorbents: Apply biochar, rice husk, or sand to improve soil aeration and absorb excess moisture.

Monitor for Diseases: Watch for yellow mosaic virus, bacterial blight, and root rot and apply organic or chemical fungicides.

Soil Aeration: Lightly till the soil after water recedes to restore oxygen levels.

Avoid Soil Compaction: Limit movement in waterlogged fields to prevent further soil damage.

Replanting Strategy: If plants are severely damaged, consider replanting with short-duration green gram varieties like Pusa Vishal.

Water Harvesting: Store rainwater in ponds for irrigation during dry spells.

Controlled Irrigation: Reduce watering frequency, as wetland soils retain moisture longer.

Raised Bed Cultivation: Improves root aeration and prevents excessive moisture buildup.

Balanced Mulching: Apply moderate mulch to conserve moisture while avoiding excess dampness.
REMEDIAL MEASURE - FLOOD:
Quick Drainage System: Construct small channels to remove standing water and prevent prolonged waterlogging.

Use Absorbents: Apply biochar, sand, or rice husk to absorb excess moisture and improve soil aeration.

Monitor for Diseases: Watch for fusarium wilt, damping-off, and bacterial blight, applying appropriate organic or chemical fungicides.

Soil Aeration: Lightly till the soil after water recedes to restore oxygen levels.

Avoid Soil Compaction: Reduce foot or machinery traffic in waterlogged fields to protect plant roots.

Replanting Strategy: If plants are severely damaged, consider replanting with short-duration green pea varieties.

Avoid Soil Compaction: Reduce foot or machinery traffic in waterlogged fields to protect plant roots.

Replanting Strategy: If plants are severely damaged, consider replanting with short-duration green pea varieties.

REMEDIAL MEASURES - DROUGHT:
Water Harvesting: Store rainwater in ponds for irrigation during dry spells.

Controlled Irrigation: Reduce watering frequency, as wetland soils retain moisture longer.

Raised Bed Cultivation: Improves root aeration and prevents excessive moisture buildup.

Balanced Mulching: Apply moderate mulch to conserve moisture while avoiding excess dampness.
REMEDIAL MEASURE - FLOOD:
Quick Drainage System: Construct small channels to remove standing water and prevent prolonged waterlogging.

Use Absorbents: Apply biochar, sand, or rice husk to absorb excess moisture and improve soil aeration.

REMEDIAL MEASURES - DROUGHT:
Water Conservation Practices: Store excess rainwater in farm ponds for later irrigation.

Raised Bed Cultivation: Enhances drainage and aeration around plant roots.

REMEDIAL MEASURE - FLOOD:
Quick Drainage System: Construct small channels to remove excess standing water quickly.

Use Absorbents: Apply biochar, rice husk, or sand to improve soil aeration and absorb excess moisture.

Monitor for Diseases: Watch for rust, leaf spot, and wilt and apply organic or chemical fungicides as needed.

Soil Aeration: After water recedes, lightly till the soil to restore oxygen and encourage new root growth.

Avoid Soil Compaction: Limit movement in the waterlogged field to prevent further soil structure damage.

Replanting Strategy: If plants are severely damaged, consider replanting with short-duration groundnut varieties.

Replanting Strategy: If plants are severely damaged, consider replanting with short-duration groundnut varieties.

Water Conservation Practices: Store rainwater in ponds for irrigation during dry spells.

Controlled Irrigation: Reduce watering frequency, as wetland soils retain moisture for longer.

Raised Bed Cultivation: Improves root aeration and prevents excessive moisture retention.

Moderate Mulching: Use a thin layer of mulch to conserve moisture while preventing excess dampness.

Quick Drainage System: Construct small channels to remove excess standing water quickly.

Use Absorbents: Apply biochar, rice husk, or sand to absorb excess moisture and improve soil aeration.

Avoid Soil Compaction: Limit movement in waterlogged fields to protect plant roots.

Replanting Strategy: If plants are severely damaged, consider replanting with short-duration lentil varieties.

Moderate Mulching: Use a thin layer of mulch to conserve moisture while preventing excess dampness.

Raised Bed Cultivation: Improves root aeration and prevents excessive moisture retention.

Moderate Mulching: Use light mulching to conserve moisture without causing excess dampness.
REMEDIAL MEASURE - FLOOD:
Quick Drainage System: Construct small drainage channels to remove stagnant water.

Use Absorbents: Apply biochar, rice husk, or sand to absorb excess moisture.

Monitor for Diseases: Watch for fusarium stalk rot, bacterial wilt, and leaf blight and apply suitable fungicides.

Soil Aeration: Lightly till the soil after water recedes to improve oxygen circulation.

Avoid Soil Compaction: Reduce movement in flooded fields to protect plant roots.

Replanting Strategy: If damage is severe, replant with short-duration maize varieties like Vivek QPM-9 or P3502.

REMEDIAL MEASURES - DROUGHT:
Water Conservation Measures: Store rainwater in farm ponds for later use.

Controlled Irrigation: Reduce watering frequency, as wetland soil retains moisture longer.

Raised Bed Cultivation: Improves root aeration and prevents excessive moisture retention.

Use of Organic Mulches: Light mulching helps in conserving soil moisture without causing excess dampness.
REMEDIAL MEASURE - FLOOD:
Quick Drainage System: Construct small channels to remove stagnant water.

Use Absorbents: Apply biochar, rice husk, or sand to absorb excess moisture and improve aeration.

Monitor for Diseases: Watch for purple blotch, basal rot, and bacterial soft rot, and apply appropriate fungicides.

Soil Aeration: Lightly till the soil after water recedes to encourage root recovery.

Avoid Soil Compaction: Reduce movement in flooded fields to protect roots.

Replanting Strategy: If bulbs rot, replant with short-duration onion varieties like Arka Niketan and Agrifound Dark Red.

Soil Aeration: Lightly till the soil after water recedes to encourage root recovery.

Avoid Soil Compaction: Reduce movement in flooded fields to protect roots.

Replanting Strategy: If bulbs rot, replant with short-duration onion varieties like Arka Niketan and Agrifound Dark Red.

REMEDIAL MEASURES - DROUGHT:
Water Conservation Measures: Store rainwater in farm ponds for later use.

Controlled Irrigation: Reduce watering frequency, as wetland soil retains moisture longer.

Raised Bed Cultivation: Improves root aeration and prevents excessive moisture retention.

Use of Organic Mulches: Light mulching helps in conserving soil moisture without causing excess dampness.
REMEDIAL MEASURE - FLOOD:
Quick Drainage System: Construct small channels to remove stagnant water.

Use Absorbents: Apply biochar, rice husk, or sand to absorb excess moisture and improve aeration.

Monitor for Diseases: Watch for purple blotch, basal rot, and bacterial soft rot, and apply appropriate fungicides.

Soil Aeration: Lightly till the soil after water recedes to encourage root recovery.

Avoid Soil Compaction: Reduce movement in flooded fields to protect roots.

Replanting Strategy: If bulbs rot, replant with short-duration onion varieties like Arka Niketan and Agrifound Dark Red.

Controlled Irrigation: Reduce watering frequency, as wetland soil retains moisture longer.

Raised Bed Cultivation: Improves root aeration and prevents excessive moisture retention.

REMEDIAL MEASURES - DROUGHT:
Water Conservation Pits: Construct small farm ponds to store excess water for later use.

Maintaining a Thin Water Layer: Instead of deep flooding, keep the water level around 2-3 cm to prevent wastage.

Use of Moisture Sensors: Helps regulate irrigation based on actual soil moisture needs.

System of Rice Intensification (SRI) Method: Involves wider spacing and alternate wetting and drying, reducing water consumption by 30-40%.
REMEDIAL MEASURE - FLOOD:
Quick Water Removal: Use drainage channels or small pumps to remove excess standing water.

Floating Rice Cultivation: If flood duration is prolonged, consider deep-water rice varieties like Jaladhi-1 or FR13A.

Use of Silica-Based Sprays: Improves resistance to lodging and stem breakage.

Aerate Soil Post-Flooding: Once water recedes, lightly till the land to improve oxygen supply.

Monitor for Pests and Diseases: Waterlogging increases rice blast, brown spot, and bacterial leaf blight; apply appropriate fungicides or biocontrol agents.

Replanting Strategy: If paddy is severely damaged, retransplant short-duration varieties like MTU 1010 or Pratiksha.

System of Rice Intensification (SRI) Method: Involves wider spacing and alternate wetting and drying, reducing water consumption by 30-40%.
REMEDIAL MEASURE - FLOOD:
Quick Water Removal: Use drainage channels or small pumps to remove excess standing water.

Floating Rice Cultivation: If flood duration is prolonged, consider deep-water rice varieties like Jaladhi-1 or FR13A.

Use of Silica-Based Sprays: Improves resistance to lodging and stem breakage.

Aerate Soil Post-Flooding: Once water recedes, lightly till the land to improve oxygen supply.

Monitor for Pests and Diseases: Waterlogging increases rice blast, brown spot, and bacterial leaf blight; apply appropriate fungicides or biocontrol agents.

Replanting Strategy: If paddy is severely damaged, retransplant short-duration varieties like MTU 1010 or Pratiksha.

System of Rice Intensification (SRI) Method: Involves wider spacing and alternate wetting and drying, reducing water consumption by 30-40%.
REMEDIAL MEASURE - FLOOD:
Quick Water Removal: Use drainage channels or small pumps to remove excess standing water.

Floating Rice Cultivation: If flood duration is prolonged, consider deep-water rice varieties like Jaladhi-1 or FR13A.

Use of Silica-Based Sprays: Improves resistance to lodging and stem breakage.

Aerate Soil Post-Flooding: Once water recedes, lightly till the land to improve oxygen supply.

Monitor for Pests and Diseases: Waterlogging increases rice blast, brown spot, and bacterial leaf blight; apply appropriate fungicides or biocontrol agents.

Replanting Strategy: If paddy is severely damaged, retransplant short-duration varieties like MTU 1010 or Pratiksha.

System of Rice Intensification (SRI) Method: Involves wider spacing and alternate wetting and drying, reducing water consumption by 30-40%.
REMEDIAL MEASURE - FLOOD:
Quick Water Removal: Use drainage channels or small pumps to remove excess standing water.

Floating Rice Cultivation: If flood duration is prolonged, consider deep-water rice varieties like Jaladhi-1 or FR13A.

Use of Silica-Based Sprays: Improves resistance to lodging and stem breakage.

Aerate Soil Post-Flooding: Once water recedes, lightly till the land to improve oxygen supply.

Monitor for Pests and Diseases: Waterlogging increases rice blast, brown spot, and bacterial leaf blight; apply appropriate fungicides or biocontrol agents.

Replanting Strategy: If paddy is severely damaged, retransplant short-duration varieties like MTU 1010 or Pratiksha.

System of Rice Intensification (SRI) Method: Involves wider spacing and alternate wetting and drying, reducing water consumption by 30-40%.
REMEDIAL MEASURE - FLOOD:
Quick Water Removal: Use drainage channels or small pumps to remove excess standing water.

Floating Rice Cultivation: If flood duration is prolonged, consider deep-water rice varieties like Jaladhi-1 or FR13A.

Use of Silica-Based Sprays: Improves resistance to lodging and stem breakage.

Aerate Soil Post-Flooding: Once water recedes, lightly till the land to improve oxygen supply.

Monitor for Pests and Diseases: Waterlogging increases rice blast, brown spot, and bacterial leaf blight; apply appropriate fungicides or biocontrol agents.

Replanting Strategy: If paddy is severely damaged, retransplant short-duration varieties like MTU 1010 or Pratiksha.

REMEDIAL MEASURES - DROUGHT:
Controlled Irrigation: Avoid overwatering, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot.

Raised Bed Planting: Improves soil aeration and prevents water stagnation.

Farm Ponds: Store excess rainwater for later use during dry spells.

Moisture Sensors: Helps regulate irrigation based on actual soil moisture needs.

Organic Mulching: Retains necessary moisture while preventing excessive dampness.
REMEDIAL MEASURE - FLOOD:
Quick Water Removal: Use drainage channels or pumps to remove standing water.

Aerate the Soil: Once water recedes, lightly till the soil to improve oxygen supply to roots.

Apply Organic Absorbents: Use sand, biochar, or rice husk to absorb excess moisture and improve aeration.

Monitor for Disease & Pest Attacks: Waterlogging increases yellow mosaic virus, anthracnose, and rustapply neem oil or appropriate fungicides.

Trim Affected Leaves: Remove yellowed or diseased leaves to prevent fungal spread.

Replanting if Necessary: If damage is severe, replant with early-maturing soybean varieties like JS 93-05.

Raised Bed Planting: Improves soil aeration and prevents water stagnation.

Farm Ponds: Store excess rainwater for later use during dry spells.

Moisture Sensors: Helps regulate irrigation based on actual soil moisture needs.

Organic Mulching: Retains necessary moisture while preventing excessive dampness.
REMEDIAL MEASURE - FLOOD:
Quick Water Removal: Use drainage channels or pumps to remove standing water.

Aerate the Soil: Once water recedes, lightly till the soil to improve oxygen supply to roots.

Apply Organic Absorbents: Use sand, biochar, or rice husk to absorb excess moisture and improve aeration.

Monitor for Disease & Pest Attacks: Waterlogging increases yellow mosaic virus, anthracnose, and rustapply neem oil or appropriate fungicides.

Trim Affected Leaves: Remove yellowed or diseased leaves to prevent fungal spread.

Replanting if Necessary: If damage is severe, replant with early-maturing soybean varieties like JS 93-05.

Organic Mulching: Retains necessary moisture while preventing excessive dampness.

REMEDIAL MEASURES - DROUGHT:
Controlled Irrigation: Avoid overwatering; supply only when soil moisture is below the required level.

Raised Bed Planting: Improves root aeration and prevents water stagnation.

Farm Ponds & Rainwater Harvesting: Store excess rainwater for use during dry spells.

Moisture Sensors & Smart Irrigation: Helps regulate irrigation based on actual soil moisture needs.

Organic Mulches & Cover Crops: Retains necessary moisture while preventing excess dampness.
REMEDIAL MEASURE - FLOOD:
Quick Drainage System: Use open drains or surface drains to remove stagnant water immediately.

Aerate the Soil: Once water recedes, loosen the soil to restore oxygen levels.

Application of Gypsum & Organic Absorbents:

Gypsum improves soil structure and drainage.

Sand, biochar, or rice husk absorbs excess moisture and enhances aeration.

Monitor for Disease & Pest Attacks:

Waterlogging increases red rot, smut, and fungal wiltapply Trichoderma or fungicides.

Pest attacks (termites, shoot borers) increaseuse neem oil or biopesticides.

Trim Affected Leaves: Remove yellowed or diseased leaves to prevent fungal spread.

Replanting if Necessary: If damage is severe, replant with early-maturing sugarcane varieties like Co 94012.

Controlled Irrigation: Avoid overwatering; supply only when soil moisture is below the required level.

Moisture Sensors & Smart Irrigation: Helps regulate irrigation based on actual soil moisture needs.

Organic Mulches & Cover Crops: Retains necessary moisture while preventing excess dampness.

Quick Drainage System: Use open drains or surface drains to remove stagnant water immediately.

Aerate the Soil: Once water recedes, loosen the soil to restore oxygen levels.

Controlled Irrigation: Avoid overwatering; supply only when soil moisture is below the required level.

Moisture Sensors & Smart Irrigation: Helps regulate irrigation based on actual soil moisture needs.

Organic Mulches & Cover Crops: Retains necessary moisture while preventing excess dampness.

Quick Drainage System: Use open drains or surface drains to remove stagnant water immediately.

Aerate the Soil: Once water recedes, loosen the soil to restore oxygen levels.

Pest attacks (termites, shoot borers) increaseuse neem oil or biopesticides.

Trim Affected Leaves: Remove yellowed or diseased leaves to prevent fungal spread.

Replanting if Necessary: If damage is severe, replant with early-maturing sugarcane varieties like Co 94012.

REMEDIAL MEASURES - DROUGHT:
Controlled Irrigation: Avoid overwatering; supply only when soil moisture is below the required level.

Raised Bed Planting: Improves root aeration and prevents water stagnation.

Farm Ponds & Rainwater Harvesting: Store excess rainwater for use during dry spells.

Moisture Sensors & Smart Irrigation: Helps regulate irrigation based on actual soil moisture needs.

Organic Mulches & Cover Crops: Retains necessary moisture while preventing excess dampness.
REMEDIAL MEASURE - FLOOD:
Quick Drainage System: Use open drains or surface drains to remove stagnant water immediately.

Aerate the Soil: Once water recedes, loosen the soil to restore oxygen levels.

Application of Gypsum & Organic Absorbents:

Gypsum improves soil structure and drainage.

Sand, biochar, or rice husk absorbs excess moisture and enhances aeration.

REMEDIAL MEASURE - FLOOD:
Quick Water Removal: Use drainage channels or pumps to remove standing water.

Aerate the Soil: Once water recedes, lightly till the soil to improve oxygen supply to roots.

Organic Absorbents: Use sand, biochar, or rice husk to absorb excess moisture.

Monitor for Disease & Pests: Waterlogging increases powdery mildew, downy mildew, and stem rotapply neem oil or appropriate fungicides.

Trim Affected Leaves: Remove yellowed or diseased leaves to prevent fungal spread.

Replanting if Necessary: If damage is severe, replant with short-duration sunflower varieties like CO-2.

REMEDIAL MEASURES - DROUGHT:
Control Excess Irrigation: Avoid frequent watering to prevent root rot.

Apply Organic Absorbents Like Biochar: Retains necessary moisture without excess dampness.

Monitor for Early Signs of Wilting & Stress: If leaves curl, apply a light irrigation with organic compost tea to improve resilience.
REMEDIAL MEASURE - FLOOD:
Immediate Water Removal to Prevent Tuber Rot:

Use drainage pipes, furrows, or field ditches to remove standing water.

Aerate the Soil to Improve Root Health: Light tilling after water recedes restores oxygen supply.

Apply Organic Absorbents Like Sand or Husk: Helps absorb excess moisture around the root zone.

Monitor for Diseases & Pest Attacks:

Waterlogging increases soft rot, wilt, and bacterial blightapply copper-based fungicides.

Increased chances of mealybug and aphid infestationsuse neem oil-based pesticides.

Trim Damaged Leaves to Prevent Fungal Spread: Removes infected foliage and improves plant recovery.

Replant with Flood-Tolerant Varieties If Needed: If damage is severe, replant with Sree Vijaya or Sree Rekha varieties.

REMEDIAL MEASURES - DROUGHT:
Controlled Irrigation to Prevent Water Stress:

Water only when the soil is dry to avoid root suffocation.

Use Organic Absorbents Like Biochar or Husk:

Helps retain necessary moisture in the soil.

Monitor for Wilting Signs:

If leaf curling occurs, apply light irrigation mixed with compost tea to improve resilience.
REMEDIAL MEASURE - FLOOD:
Ensure Quick Water Removal:

Use surface drains, furrows, or raised beds to avoid prolonged water stagnation.

Aerate the Soil Once Floodwater Recedes:

Light tilling helps restore oxygen supply to roots.

Use Organic Absorbents Like Sand or Rice Husk:

Helps absorb excess moisture and prevents waterlogging.

Monitor for Disease & Pest Attacks:

Waterlogging increases the chances of fungal infections like late blight and bacterial wiltapply copper fungicides.

Aphids, whiteflies, and nematodes become common after floodsuse neem oil-based biopesticides.

Trim Affected Leaves to Prevent Fungal Spread:

Remove yellow or infected leaves to improve plant recovery.

Replant Flood-Resistant Varieties If Needed:

If plants are severely damaged, replant with tolerant varieties like Arka Rakshak or Punjab Kesari.
